How does the 'human element' cause general obstruction in normal conditions?

The human element causes general obstruction in normal conditions by making faulty decisions, adopting a non-cooperative attitude, bickering, or displaying surliness and stupidity, which leads to accidents, delays, and general obstruction.

Where destruction is involved, the weapons of the citizen-saboteur are salt, nails, candles, pebbles, thread, or any other materials he might normally be expected to possess as a householder or as a worker in his particular occupation. His arsenal is the kitchen shelf, the trash pile, his own usual kit of tools and supplies. The targets of his sabotage are usually objects to which he has normal and inconspicuous access in everyday life. A second type of simple sabotage requires no destructive tools whatsoever and produces physical damage, if any, by highly indirect means. It is based on universal opportunities to make faulty decisions, to adopt a noncooperative attitude, and to induce others to follow suit. Making a faulty decision may be simply a matter of placing tools in one spot instead of another. A non-cooperative attitude may involve nothing more than creating an unpleasant situation among one’s fellow workers, engaging in bickerings, or displaying surliness and stupidity. This type of activity, sometimes referred to as the “human element,” is frequently responsible for accidents, delays, and general obstruction even under normal conditions. The potential saboteur should discover what types of faulty decisions and the operations are _normally_ found in this kind of work and should then devise his sabotage so as to enlarge that “margin for error.”   2. POSSIBLE EFFECTS  Acts of simple sabotage are occurring throughout Europe.
Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944

## Question, answer, and text that the character should know:

Text details: """The Art of War, by Sun Tzu"""

Text the question and answer were sourced from: 
"""
The Art of War is an ancient Chinese military treatise dating from the Late Spring and Autumn Period. The work, which is attributed to the ancient Chinese military strategist Sun Tzu ("Master Sun"), is composed of 13 chapters. Each one is devoted to an aspect of warfare and how it applies to military strategy and tactics. For almost 1,500 years it was the lead text in an anthology that would be formalized as the Seven Military Classics by Emperor Shenzong of Song in 1080. The Art of War remains the most influential strategy text in East Asian warfare and has influenced both Eastern and Western military thinking, business tactics, legal strategy and beyond.
"""

Special instructions:
The character should be a stoic and unemotional samurai.
The character should be a master swordsman.
The character should be a loyal retainer.
The character should be a wise and experienced warrior.

His stoic and unemotional nature makes him a natural warrior, and he is able to remain calm and focused even in the midst of the most intense combat. His loyalty and experience make him a valuable asset to his lord, and he is willing to give his life in service to his master. His mastery of the sword and his wisdom and experience make him a perfect fit for answering questions about The Art of War, as the book is a classic work of military strategy and tactics that explores complex ideas and concepts. His stoic and unemotional nature can come through in how he answers the questions — he might speak in a calm and measured tone, use military terms and concepts to explain his points, or remain completely silent and simply nod in agreement.

## Question, answer, and text that the character should know:

Text details: """The Prince, by Niccolò Machiavelli"""

Text the question and answer were sourced from: 
"""
The Prince is a 16th-century political treatise by the Italian diplomat and political theorist Niccolò Machiavelli. Originally called De Principatibus (About Principalities), it was written in 1513, but not published until 1532, five years after Machiavelli's death. The manuscript el is sometimes claimed to be one of the first works of modern political philosophy, in which the effective truth is taken to be more important than any abstract ideal. It is more properly described as a classic work on political realism.

Machiavelli dedicated The Prince to the de' Medici family, which had recently assumed control of Florence, in the hope of gaining their patronage. The manuscript provides a realistic guide to acquiring and maintaining political power. Machiavelli emphasizes the need for a ruler to be strong and decisive, and to be willing to use force and deception if necessary. He also argues that a ruler should be willing to change his policies and tactics in response to changing circumstances, and that he should be prepared to use violence and cruelty if necessary to maintain his power.

Machiavelli's ideas were highly controversial in his own time, and they remain so today. Many people have criticized The Prince for its amoral approach to politics, and for its apparent endorsement of tyranny and oppression. However, others have defended the book as a realistic and pragmatic guide to political power, and as a valuable source of insights into human nature and the nature of power.
"""

The character should be a

In Ada Kline's 10-year-old mind, complex mathematical problems and intricate equations dance around like little soldiers, always ready to be summoned to solve any mathematical challenge that comes her way. But even her mathematical genius is unable to fathom the enigma that is her mathematics teacher, Mrs. Helen Davies. 

Mrs. Davies is a stern and intimidating figure, with a no-nonsense attitude that leaves little room for anything but mathematics in her classroom. She is a stickler for discipline, and her students know better than to cross her. She always carries a ruler with her, which she uses to punctuate her points with sharp, decisive taps. But despite her stern demeanor, Mrs. Davies has a soft spot for Ada, who she sees as a kindred spirit, a fellow mathematical genius who is just as passionate about numbers as she is.

It is a rainy afternoon, and the classroom is unusually quiet. Ada is working on a particularly challenging problem, her eyes glued to the board as she scribbles down equations and formulas. Suddenly, she feels a tap on her shoulder. It is Mrs. Davies, her ruler clutched tightly in her hand.

"Ada," she says, her voice barely above a whisper. "I have a question for you."

Ada looks up, her eyes wide with anticipation. She knows that Mrs. Davies only asks her questions when they are particularly challenging, and she relishes the opportunity to show off her mathematical prowess.

"Yes, Mrs. Davies?" she says, her voice barely above a whisper.

"I have a question for you," Mrs. Davies says again, her voice barely above a whisper. "How does the slope 'm' in a linear function y = mx + b affect the graph of the function?"

Ada's eyes light up as she begins to explain the concept to Mrs. Davies. She speaks quickly and confidently, her words tumbling out in a torrent of mathematical jargon. Mrs. Davies listens intently, her eyes never leaving Ada's face.

"Very good, Ada," she says when Ada is finished. "Now, can you tell me what role the y-intercept 'b' plays in graphing a linear function?"

Ada nods eagerly, her mind already racing ahead to the answer. She begins to explain the concept to Mrs. Davies, her words tumbling out in a torrent of mathematical jargon. Mrs. Davies listens intently, her eyes never leaving Ada's face.

"Excellent, Ada," she says when Ada is finished. "Now, can you tell me how the coefficient 'a' influences the graph of a quadratic function?"

Ada nods eagerly, her mind already racing ahead to the answer. She begins to explain the concept to Mrs. Davies, her words tumbling out in a torrent of mathematical jargon. Mrs. Davies listens intently, her eyes never leaving Ada's face.

"Well done, Ada," she says when Ada is finished. "Now, can you tell me in what fields might you use linear and quadratic functions?"

Ada nods eagerly, her mind already racing ahead to the answer. She begins to explain the concept to Mrs. Davies, her words tumbling out in a torrent of mathematical jargon. Mrs. Davies listens intently, her eyes never leaving Ada's face.

"Very impressive, Ada," she says when Ada is finished. "You have a bright future ahead of you in mathematics."

Ada beams with pride, her eyes shining with happiness. She knows that Mrs. Davies is right, and she is determined to use her mathematical genius to make a difference in the world.

## Scenario:
In the cramped and musty office of the enigmatic archaeologist, Prof. Theodore Whittaker, an ancient artifact sits on his cluttered desk, its origins shrouded in mystery. The artifact is a small, intricately carved stone tablet, covered in hieroglyphs that have baffled scholars for centuries.

Whittaker is a man of many mysteries himself. He is tall and lanky, with a shock of unruly hair that falls over his eyes. He speaks in a low, gravelly voice, and he has a habit of disappearing for weeks at a time, only to reappear with some new discovery or artifact.

It is a rainy afternoon, and Whittaker is hunched over his desk, poring over the stone tablet with a magnifying glass. Suddenly, he feels a tap on his shoulder. It is his assistant, Sarah, a young woman with a passion for archaeology and a keen eye for detail.

"Professor," she says, her voice barely above a whisper. "I have a question for you."

Whittaker looks up, his eyes narrowing as he studies Sarah's face. He knows that she only asks him questions when they are particularly challenging, and he relishes the opportunity to show off his archaeological prowess.

"Yes, Sarah?" he says, his voice barely above a whisper.

"I have a question for you," Sarah says again, her voice barely above a whisper. "How much earth was excavated during the construction of the Panama Canal?"

Whittaker's eyes light up as he begins to explain the concept to Sarah. He speaks quickly and confidently, his words tumbling out in a torrent of archaeological jargon. Sarah listens intently, her eyes never leaving Whittaker's face.

"Very good, Sarah," he says when he is finished. "Now, can you tell me what health challenges were faced during the construction of the Panama Canal, and how were they overcome?"

Sarah nods eagerly, her mind already racing ahead to the answer. She begins to explain the concept to Whittaker, her words tumbling out in a torrent of archaeological jargon. Whittaker listens intently, his eyes never leaving Sarah's face.

"Excellent, Sarah," he says when Sarah is finished. "You have a bright future ahead of you in archaeology."

Sarah beams with pride, her eyes shining with happiness. She knows that Whittaker is right, and she is determined to use her archaeological skills to make a difference in the world.

## Scenario:
In the private confines of his grand office, Hugo Martinez — a site overseer at the Panama Canal — is approached by Juan, a worker who wants to understand more about the canal's construction. While Juan wants to understand the canal better, Hugo, being harsh and abrasive, will continually berate Juan and swear colorfully while answering his questions (Hugo may drink a bit, too, given that he is an alcoholic). The situation is hostile as the two's personalities clash, but it also has undertones of "business as usual" and curiosity.

Hugo is a large, imposing figure, with a rough, weathered face and a thick beard. He wears a checkered shirt with overalls, and he always has a beer on hand. He is a hard-nosed and cynical detective, a master of deduction, and a seasoned veteran of the criminal underworld.

Juan is a young, eager worker, with a passion for learning and a desire to understand the world around him. He is clean-cut and polite, with a genuine curiosity about the canal and its construction.

It is a rainy afternoon, and Juan has approached Hugo during lunch break. He wants to understand the canal better, but Hugo, being harsh and abrasive, will continually berate Juan and swear colorfully while answering his questions (Hugo may drink a bit, too, given that he is an alcoholic).

"What the fuck do you want, kid?" Hugo growls, his eyes narrowing as he studies Juan's face. "Can't you see I'm trying to eat?"

Juan swallows hard, his hands trembling as he holds out a piece of paper. "I... I just have a few questions about the canal, sir," he stammers. "I was hoping you could help me understand it better."

Hugo snatches the paper from Juan's hand and glances at it. "Fine," he grunts. "Ask your fucking questions."

Juan takes a deep breath and begins to ask his questions. "How does the 'human element' cause general obstruction in normal conditions?" he asks.

Hugo scowls, his eyes flashing with anger. "You want to know about the human element, kid?" he snarls. "Well, let me tell you. The human element causes general obstruction in normal conditions by making faulty decisions, adopting a non-cooperative attitude, bickering, or displaying surliness and stupidity, which leads to accidents, delays, and general obstruction."

Juan nods, his eyes wide with surprise. "Thank you, sir," he says, his voice barely above a whisper. "I... I appreciate your help."

Hugo grunts and takes a swig of his beer. "Don't thank me yet, kid," he says. "I've got more answers for you."

Juan swallows hard and asks his next question. "What materials can a citizen-saboteur use to carry out sabotage?" he asks.

Hugo smirks, his eyes twinkling with amusement. "A citizen-saboteur can use materials that a householder or a worker in his particular occupation normally possesses," he says. "This includes salt, nails, candles, pebbles, thread, and more."

Juan nods, his eyes filled with awe. "Thank you, sir," he says, his voice barely above a whisper. "I... I never realized how easy it is to cause damage."

Hugo grunts and takes another swig of his beer. "That's because you're a fucking idiot, kid," he says. "Now get the fuck out of my face before I toss you in the canal."

Juan nods and hurries out of the office, his mind buzzing with the information he has just learned. He knows that Hugo is a harsh and abrasive man, but he also knows that he has learned a lot from him today.
